title: 111_s1067
content: SEC. 4. REQUIREMENT OF A STRATEGY TO SUPPORT THE DISARMAMENT OF THE LORD'S RESISTANCE ARMY. The President must develop and submit a strategy within 180 days to Congress to support efforts to eliminate the threat posed by the Lord's Resistance Army and protect civilians in the region. The strategy to support efforts to eliminate the threat posed by the Lord's Resistance Army includes developing institutions in affected areas, assessing viable options with regional governments, creating an interagency framework for coordination, and engaging diplomatically across the region. The strategy to support efforts to eliminate the threat posed by the Lord's Resistance Army includes developing institutions in affected areas, assessing viable options with regional governments, creating an interagency framework for coordination, and engaging diplomatically across the region. Additionally, humanitarian assistance will be provided to areas outside Uganda affected by the Lord's Resistance Army, and assistance for recovery and reconstruction in northern Uganda will be given. Assistance for recovery and reconstruction in northern Uganda includes supporting internally displaced people and returnees, enhancing local governance institutions, and strengthening the civilian police to improve public safety. The assistance in northern Uganda aims to enhance public safety, prevent crime, rebuild the justice system, disarm former combatants, and address psychosocial trauma. The Secretary of State and Administrator of the United States Agency for International Development should increase assistance to support transparent and accountable reconstruction in war-affected areas of northern Uganda. This includes finalizing mechanisms to manage programs under the Peace Recovery and Development Plan, increasing oversight activities, and committing substantial funds. The United States should coordinate with other donor nations to increase contributions for recovery efforts in northern Uganda and encourage transparent and accountable reconstruction. If the Government of Uganda is not committed to reconstruction and reconciliation in war-affected areas, non-humanitarian bilateral assistance should be withheld. The United States should support reconciliation and transitional justice efforts in northern Uganda to prevent perpetuating political grievances and fueling conflicts. The President is authorized to assist in promoting these efforts on local and national levels. The Agreement on Accountability and Reconciliation between the Government of Uganda and the Lord's Resistance Army/Movement, signed in Juba on February 19, 2008, outlines mechanisms including an investigative body, a special court division for serious crimes, a reparations system for conflict victims. The Agreement on Accountability and Reconciliation between the Government of Uganda and the Lord's Resistance Army/Movement includes mechanisms for reparations to conflict victims and a strategy for transitional justice. A report on the progress of implementing the strategy must be submitted to Congress within a year. The report required by Congress includes details on the implementation of the strategy, assistance provided to Uganda, evaluation of bilateral assistance, status of the Peace Recovery and Development Plan, and amounts of assistance committed to northern Uganda. The report should be submitted in unclassified form, with a possible classified annex. Congress believes that a portion of the appropriations for the fiscal year should be allocated accordingly. In fiscal year 2011, up to $10,000,000 should be used for activities under sections 5 and 7 of the Department of State and foreign operations appropriations. Definitions in the Act include the term "appropriate committees of Congress" and "Great Lakes Region" referring to specific regions. The region includes Burundi, Democratic Republic of Congo, Rwanda, southern Sudan, and Uganda. LRA-affected areas are defined as parts of northern Uganda, southern Sudan, northeastern Democratic Republic of Congo, and southeastern Central African Republic affected by the Lord's Resistance Army.
